questions.answer_description:
Box 1: Assign a tag to each resource.
You apply tags to your Azure resources giving metadata to logically organize them into a taxonomy. After you apply tags, you can retrieve all the resources in your subscription with that tag name and value. Each resource or resource group can have a maximum of 15 tag name/value pairs. Tags applied to the resource group are not inherited by the resources in that resource group.
Box 2: From the Cost analysis blade, filter the view by tag
After you get your services running, regularly check how much they're costing you. You can see the current spend and burn rate in Azure portal.
1. Visit the Subscriptions blade in Azure portal and select a subscription.
You should see the cost breakdown and burn rate in the popup blade.
2. Click Cost analysis in the list to the left to see the cost breakdown by resource. Wait 24 hours after you add a service for the data to populate.
3. You can filter by different properties like tags, resource group, and timespan. Click Apply to confirm the filters and Download if you want to export the view to a
Comma-Separated Values (.csv) file.
Box 3: Download the usage report
Reference:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/azure-resource-manager/resource-group-using-tags https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/billing/billing-getting-started

discussion.content: given answer is correct

Go to Cost Management + Billing on the left side blade; 5. Select Cost Management in Cost Management + Billing blade; 6. Click on Cost Analysis, set filter by tag set previously, and Download from the top side.
Here the answer short the steps, but it's right.
correct answer tagging is imp

questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP -
You have an Azure subscription that is used by four departments in your company. The subscription contains 10 resource groups. Each department uses resources in several resource groups.
You need to send a report to the finance department. The report must detail the costs for each department.
Which three actions should you perform in sequence? To answer, move the appropriate actions from the list of actions to the answer area and arrange them in the correct order.
Select and Place:
//IMG//

Note: This question is part of a series of questions that present the same scenario. Each question in the series contains a unique solution that might meet the stated goals. Some question sets might have more than one correct solution, while others might not have a correct solution.
After you answer a question in this section, you will NOT be able to return to it. As a result, these questions will not appear in the review screen.
You have an Azure Active Directory (Azure AD) tenant named Adatum and an Azure Subscription named Subscription1. Adatum contains a group named
Developers. Subscription1 contains a resource group named Dev.
You need to provide the Developers group with the ability to create Azure logic apps in the Dev resource group.
Solution: On Subscription1, you assign the Logic App Operator role to the Developers group.
Does this meet the goal?

questions.question_text:
Your company has an Azure subscription named Subscription1.
The company also has two on-premises servers named Server1 and Server2 that run Windows Server 2016. Server1 is configured as a DNS server that has a primary DNS zone named adatum.com. Adatum.com contains 1,000 DNS records.
You manage Server1 and Subscription1 from Server2. Server2 has the following tools installed:
✑ The DNS Manager console
✑ Azure PowerShell
✑ Azure CLI 2.0
You need to move the adatum.com zone to Subscription1. The solution must minimize administrative effort.
What should you use?

choices.A: Generate an automation script for RG1.

questions.answer_description:
As an administrator, you may need to lock a subscription, resource group, or resource to prevent other users in your organization from accidentally deleting or modifying critical resources.
ReadOnly means authorized users can read a resource, but they can't delete or update the resource. Applying this lock is similar to restricting all authorized users to the permissions granted by the Reader role.
Incorrect Answers:
C: A ReadOnly lock on a resource group that contains a virtual machine prevents all users from starting or restarting the virtual machine. These operations require a POST request.
References:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/azure-resource-manager/resource-group-lock-resources

discussion.content: A is correct

A is correct
A is correct

A read-only lock on a storage account prevents users from listing the account keys. The Azure Storage List Keys operation is handled through a POST request to protect access to the account keys, which provide complete access to data in the storage account. When a read-only lock is configured for a storage account, users who don't have the account keys must use Azure AD credentials to access blob or queue data. A read-only lock also prevents the assignment of Azure RBAC roles that are scoped to the storage account or to a data container (blob container or queue).

So B, C, D are incorrect. We are left with A, seems to be correct.

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/azure-resource-manager/management/lock-resources?tabs=json


A read-only lock on a storage account prevents users from listing the account keys. The Azure Storage List Keys operation is handled through a POST request to protect access to the account keys

Well, if the question ReadOnly lock is working on RG1, then here need automation script. So option A is correct. But if the question is ReadOnly lock to Storageaccount1, option B is correct. Therefore, check the question carefully when doing the exam. I do belive every time, they only slightly change one or two key words from the question then the answer is different.

Applying ReadOnly can lead to unexpected results because some operations that don't seem to modify the resource actually require actions that are blocked by the lock. The ReadOnly lock can be applied to the resource or to the resource group containing the resource. Some common examples of the operations that are blocked by a ReadOnly lock are:

questions.question_text:
You have a resource group named RG1. RG1 contains an Azure Storage account named storageaccount1 and a virtual machine named VM1 that runs Windows
Server 2016. Storageaccount1 contains the disk files for VM1.
You apply a ReadOnly lock to RG1.
What can you do from the Azure portal?

questions.answer_description:
Box 1: "tag1": "value1" only -
Box 2: "tag2": "value2" and "tag3": "value3"
Tags applied to the resource group are not inherited by the resources in that resource group.
References:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/azure-resource-manager/resource-group-using-tags

comments.content: The given answer is correct. Append tag policy can be done for resource groups too and the policy tags will be applied only when resource group is created or updated. The question says the append tag has no exclusions meaning resource group would also have the tag, had it been created after the policy.

discussion.content: I also think it is important to point out "Appends the specified tag and value when any resource which is missing this tag is created or updated. Does not modify the tags of resources created before this policy was applied until those resources are changed. Does not apply to resource groups."
ANswer is correct ..tested and verified
Correct

Question designed to make you waste time on your exam. 
Answer is correct.

So the answer is correct yet the explanation, while correct at face value, is not the reason why RG1 only has Tag 1 applied. Here is the explanation from Azure when actually creating a policy: "By default, this assignment will only take effect on newly created resources. Existing resources can be updated via a remediation task after the policy is assigned." Tags aren't inherited but policies apply to everything downstream from the group it was applied to, minus any exceptions.

The answer is correct. For resource group, it's created as first step and the policy is created as 'append' which means the tags in policy will append to the resources as extra, not replace any previouse tags. Therefore, it's clear now. RG1 has one group of tag: tag1 and value1. Storage has two groups of tag: tag3, value3 and tag2, value2 appending from policy.
Exam Question 12/23/2020

There is a policy here: https://github.com/Azure/azure-policy/tree/master/samples/built-in-policy/apply-default-tag-value
In the source code for this policy, it notes:
 "description": "Appends the specified tag and value when any resource which is missing this tag is created or updated. Does not modify the tags of resources created before this policy was applied until those resources are changed. Does not apply to resource groups. New 'modify' effect policies are available that support remediation of tags on existing resources (see https://aka.ms/modifydoc).",

discussion.content:
The answer is correct in the context of how it is presented, but I believe this question is poorly constructed. 

There is no built in policy listed "Append tag and its default value" at https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/azure-resource-manager/management/tag-policies.

Therefore, I believe the intent of this question is on a Custom Policy and on policy effects in relation to the behaviour of an (intended) Append. 
This article https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/governance/policy/concepts/effects#modify describes the Order of Evaluation and the Modify effect as the preferred way to work with tags including Append.
Secondly, Azure Policy is evaluated on "creation" and then on a compliance evaluation cycle - every 24 hours. https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/governance/policy/overview#understand-evaluation-outcomes

The answer is correct:
"Does not modify the tags of resources created before this policy was applied until those resources are changed. Does not apply to resource groups"

https://github.com/Azure/azure-policy/blob/02f0c83c3c4fbdd72fcfcd54ac63a93a8e2fa071/samples/built-in-policy/apply-default-tag-value/README.md

agreed, correct answer. basically, the enforcement from the superior subscription > Resource Group > Resource is possible ONLY if the policy is already created prior to the creation of RG or Resource. In this case the RG was already created and policy from the subscription cannot be enforced to RG. but the resource will have that.

The answers are correct. Tags applied to the resource group or subscription aren't inherited by the resources. To apply tags from a subscription or resource group to the resources, see Azure Policies - tags.
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/azure-resource-manager/management/tag-policies

Correct...
Dose not modify the tag of RG created before this policy was applied

comments.content:
But the tag defined here is applied only on resource not resource groupe.
So the answer is correct

discussion.content: Tags are not inherited from subs or rgs, however in this case, a policy is applied on this sub meaning all resources created in this sub will be forced with this tag policy.

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
You have an Azure subscription named Subscription1 that contains the following resource group:
✑ Name: RG1
✑ Region: West US
✑ Tag: "tag1": "value1"
You assign an Azure policy named Policy1 to Subscription1 by using the following configurations:
✑ Exclusions: None
✑ Policy definition: Append tag and its default value
✑ Assignment name: Policy1
✑ Parameters:
- Tag name: Tag2
- Tag value: Value2
After Policy1 is assigned, you create a storage account that has the following configurations:
✑ Name: storage1
✑ Location: West US
✑ Resource group: RG1
✑ Tags: "tag3": "value3"
You need to identify which tags are assigned to each resource.
What should you identify? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:
//IMG//
